nodes.text: Are intergenerational income mobility outcomes in the United States for children born 1971-1993 different from those for children born in the 1970s (i.e., has mobility declined)?
Population-based sample: linked parent-child tax records (1996-2012) for individuals born 1980-1993; roughly 95 percent linkage per cohort and 3.7 million children per cohort in files used
SOI sample: Statistics of Income stratified cross sections (1987 onward) used to construct representative samples for 1971-1982 cohorts; sampling weights imply roughly 88 percent cohort coverage

Variable definitions: parent family income (mean over child ages 15-19 in population sample, single year in SOI), child family income (mean at ages 29-30 or 26), college attendance = 1098-T at age 19; observations with zero/negative parent income dropped

Estimation method: rank-rank specification regressing child income percentile rank on parent income percentile rank by birth cohort (OLS on binned data), supplemented by quintile transition matrices and college-attendance gradients
Result: The copula (joint distribution of parent and child ranks) has not changed over time; rank-based measures of mobility, including rank-rank slopes, are stable across cohorts
Result: Marginal income distributions for parents and children have widened substantially over time; measured by increases in Gini coefficients and top 1 percent shares

Evidence: Consolidated mobility series (combining age 29-30 income gradients, scaled age 26 gradients, and scaled college gradients) is essentially flat for 1971-1993 cohorts; estimated trend −0.0006 per year with 95% upper bound 0.0008

Result: College attendance gradient (difference in college attendance between lowest- and highest-income parents) is roughly constant at 74.5 percent for 1984–1989 cohorts and only slightly lower for recent cohorts (69.2 percent for 1993)

Evidence: Quintile transition probabilities are stable across cohorts; probability of moving from bottom parental quintile to top child quintile ~8.4% in 1971 and ~9.0% in 1986 (child income at age 26)
Claim: Because marginal inequality increased while rank mobility was stable, the economic consequences of the 'birth lottery' (parental income differences) are larger today than in the past

Result: Large, persistent regional differences in mobility exist across US areas (e.g., bottom-to-top quintile transition ~4% in some Southeastern areas vs over 12% in Mountain states); regional gradients are stable though with modest differential trends

Assumption: Forecasting recent cohorts' age-30 mobility uses age-26 income and college-attendance gradients scaled by constant factors (age-26 scaled by 1.12, college scaled by 0.40) assuming stable proportional relationships to age-30 gradients

Conclusion: Rank-based measures of intergenerational income mobility in the United States remained stable from 1971 through 1993 cohorts despite substantial rises in income inequality, implying unchanged rank persistence but larger absolute gaps due to wider marginals
